title: The Downfall of the 2015 World Series Champions, The Kansas City Royals
text:
Since winning it all, the Royals have strung together some rather atrocious seasons. To be a playoff caliber ball club, you must excel on both sides of the game, offense and defense which the Royals haven’t seemed to do.
The story that I’m aiming to tell here is the downfall of the Kansas City Royals since winning the World Series in 2015. I hypothesize that since 2015 the Royals have fallen well below average in three different phases of the game: Pitching, Fielding, and Batting. In order to investigate the Royals on these three phases, we need to look at change over time (2015-2022). The metrics I’ve chosen to look at are Earned Run Average (ERA) for Pitching, Defensive Efficiency (% of balls in play converted into outs) for Fielding, and Batting Average (hits/at bats) for Batting.


Code
library(tidyverse)

pitching15 <- read_csv("pitchingdata2015.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2015)
pitching16 <- read_csv("pitchingdata2016.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2016)
pitching17 <- read_csv("pitchingdata2017.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2017)
pitching18 <- read_csv("pitchingdata2018.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2018)
pitching19 <- read_csv("pitchingdata2019.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2019)
pitching20 <- read_csv("pitchingdata2020.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2020)
pitching21 <- read_csv("pitchingdata2021.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2021)
pitching22 <- read_csv("pitchingdata2022.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2022)

pitching <- bind_rows(pitching15, pitching16, pitching17, pitching18, pitching19, pitching20, pitching21, pitching22)

yalsP<- pitching %>% 
  filter(Tm =="Kansas City Royals") 
  averageERA<- pitching %>% 
    group_by(Season) %>% 
    summarise(mean_ERA=mean(ERA))
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=pitching, aes(x=Season, y=ERA, group=Tm), color="light grey") +
  geom_line(data=yalsP, aes(x=Season, y=ERA), color="blue") +
  geom_line(data=averageERA, aes(x=Season, y=mean_ERA), color="black")+
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(2, 6)) +
labs(
    x="Year", 
    y="ERA", 
    title="Royals Pitching Has Suffered Since Winning It All", 
    subtitle="KC's Average ERA isn't stacking up against the competition", 
    caption="Source: Sports-Reference | By Carter Nab"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
      plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 14), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 





Based on each MLB team’s Earned Run Average the only seasons the Royals were better than the average was in 2015(World Series Champs), and 2020(Covid-19 season).
It’s clear that the strength of the Royals bullpen isn’t what it was in 2015, as they appear to be continually moving away from the average year after year with exception to the shortened Covid-19 season.


Code
library(tidyverse)

fielding15 <- read_csv("fieldingdata2015.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2015)
fielding16 <- read_csv("fieldingdata2016.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2016)
fielding17 <- read_csv("fieldingdata2017.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2017)
fielding18 <- read_csv("fieldingdata2018.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2018)
fielding19 <- read_csv("fieldingdata2019.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2019)
fielding20 <- read_csv("fieldingdata2020.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2020)
fielding21 <- read_csv("fieldingdata2021.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2021)
fielding22 <- read_csv("fieldingdata2022.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2022)

fielding <- bind_rows(fielding15, fielding16, fielding17, fielding18, fielding19, fielding20, fielding21, fielding22)

yalsD<- fielding %>% 
  filter(Tm =="Kansas City Royals") %>%
  select(Season, Tm, DefEff) %>%
  mutate(teamseason=paste(Season, Tm))
averageDefEff<- fielding %>% 
    group_by(Season) %>% 
  summarise(DefEff=mean(DefEff)) %>% 
  mutate(Tm="Average")

combined<- bind_rows(yalsD, averageDefEff) %>% 
  mutate(teamseason=paste(Season, Tm))

ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=combined, aes(x=reorder(teamseason,-Season), weight=DefEff, group=Tm), fill="light grey") +
  geom_bar(data=yalsD, aes(x=reorder(teamseason,-Season), weight=DefEff), fill="#004687") +
  #geom_line(data=yalsD, aes(x=Season, y=DefEff), color="blue") +
  #geom_line(data=averageDefEff, aes(x=Season, y=mean_DefEff), color="black") +
  coord_flip() +
  labs(
    x="Year", 
    y="Defensive Efficiency", 
    title="Royals Defense is Below Average Since 2015", 
    subtitle="KC's Defense needs some help if they want to ever make it to the playoffs again",
    caption="Source: Sports-Reference | By Carter Nab"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
      plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 14), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 





hex= #004687 Defensive Efficiency calculates the percentage of balls hit into play that are turned into outs. Most teams at the professional level are quite good at this so the deviation from team to team stays with-in about 10%.
The only time in the last seven years the Royals were above the league average was in 2015, since then they continue to move further below average and were particularly bad in this 2022 season.


Code
library(tidyverse)

batting15 <- read_csv("battingdata2015.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2015)
batting16 <- read_csv("battingdata2016.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2016)
batting17 <- read_csv("battingdata2017.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2017)
batting18 <- read_csv("battingdata2018.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2018)
batting19 <- read_csv("battingdata2019.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2019)
batting20 <- read_csv("battingdata2020.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2020)
batting21 <- read_csv("battingdata2021.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2021)
batting22 <- read_csv("battingdata2022.csv") %>% mutate(Season = 2022)

batting <- bind_rows(batting15, batting16, batting17, batting18, batting19, batting20, batting21, batting22)

yalsO<- batting %>% 
  filter(Tm =="Kansas City Royals")
averageBA<- batting %>% 
    group_by(Season) %>% 
  summarise(mean_BattingAVG=mean(BA))
ggplot() + 
  geom_line(data=batting, aes(x=Season, y=BA, group=Tm), color="light grey") +
  geom_line(data=yalsO, aes(x=Season, y=BA), color="blue") +
  geom_line(data=averageBA, aes(x=Season, y=mean_BattingAVG), color="black") +
  labs(
    x="Year", 
    y="Batting Average", 
    title="Royals Batting Average Is Heading In The Wrong Direction", 
    subtitle="KC's front office should invest in some better hitters if they want to be relevant again",
    caption="Source: Sports-Reference | By Carter Nab"
    ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
      plot.title = element_text(size = 18, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 14), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=12), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
    ) 





Compared to the last two charts that analyzed the defensive phases of the game, this chart takes a look at the offensive side of the game represented by each teams batting average over the last seven years.
While this still shows constant decline the Royals have managed to remain much closer to the leagues average compared to their defensive phases but it’s clear that the Royals offense hasn’t made significant progress since their World Series season.
In order for the Kansas City Royals to become relevant in the MLB again, the front office will definitely need to re-access the members of the team and attain some new athletes that find into the puzzel of a quality baseball team.
